metadata.case_name: Hari alias Dada Khemu Gawali v. Deputy Commissioner of Police, Crime Branch (C.I.D.), Greater Bombay and State of Bombay

facts.text: Petitioner is a citizen of India, born in Bombay, residing in quarters in City of Bombay, owns bullock carts for transport business and company for selling milk.
Prohibition Police instituted twelve prohibition cases against petitioner, all ended in discharge or acquittal.
Externment order passed against petitioner in August 1950, set aside by Government in December 1950 on appeal.

Detention order passed against petitioner under Preventive Detention Act, 1950 in December 1953, detained in Thana District prison, petition under Art 226 to Bombay High Court, released before hearing.
Petitioner along with others charged with possession of liquor, case lasted two years, discharged by Presidency Magistrate on 24th February 1955 due to prosecution witnesses not present.

On night of 9th October 1954, petitioner arrested with companions after midnight by Ghost Squad (special wing Crime Branch C.I.D.), alleged they ran on sight of police van, chased, arrested with knives and weapons.

Notice served on petitioner in October 1954 under s.57 read with s.59 Bombay Police Act, 1951, alleging conviction on 14-10-1938 under s.304/109 IPC 6 yrs RI, concurrent 2 yrs under 127/38 PCR; arrests in 1948 and 1949 cases discharged for lack of evidence; arrested 9-10-1954 with 7 others armed with weapons, suspected to commit offence under Ch XVI/XVII IPC.
Petitioner appeared before Superintendent on 8th November 1954 with counsel, filed written statement denying allegations except conviction, claimed clean life since 1938.

Externment order passed by first respondent (Deputy Commissioner) on 8th November 1954 under s.57, directing removal outside Greater Bombay for 2 years after pending case, no re-entry without permission.
Petitioner appealed to Government of Bombay against externment order, appeal dismissed.
Petitioner's 1938 conviction: guilty with brother Rajaram of causing death of person who gave evidence against them.

Since 1948, petitioner involved in cases of violence: March 1948 police constable assaulted (not charge-sheeted); April 1948 brother charged him with rioting (discharged want of evidence); May 1949 rescued arrested persons including brother (discharged witnesses absent); 9 Oct 1954 arrested with 7 others armed, smelling alcohol, acquitted due to discrepancies.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 57 of Bombay Police Act, 1951 contravenes Articles 19(1)(d) and (e) by imposing unreasonable restrictions on freedom of movement and residence.
Whether the externment order under s.57 is illegal as based on vague allegations and inadmissible material like discharges/acquittals.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 57 vests unlimited powers in police to extern from areas including entire State, no Advisory Board check unlike preventive detention, hearing and appeal illusory as police is prosecutor and judge, offences clubbed irrationally.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 19(1)(d),(e); precedents: Chintaman Rao v. State of MP, State of Madras v. VG Row, etc.

petitioner_arguments.text: Externment order based on old conviction, discharges/acquittals due to lack of evidence, vague allegations.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner fully heard before order; history of violence since 1948, previous conviction under Ch XVI IPC, recent arrest armed, likely to repeat offences; material examined justified satisfaction.

court_reasoning.text: S.57 preventive measure based on sound principle to curb repeat criminals for public order; restrictions reasonable as require prior conviction and belief of repetition; not unlimited as local jurisdiction; no need for Advisory Board; procedure under s.59 fair, appeal to Govt real; discharges can be considered as witnesses may be intimidated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Balance individual rights with community interests; upheld like s.27 City Police Act in Gurbachan Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Order not arbitrary, based on conviction and material showing violence pattern; not for court to re-examine subjective satisfaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discharges due to witness absence/intimidation relevant for preventive action.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Jagannadhadas J.): S.57 unreasonable as not limited to serious offences or witness unavailability; prior conviction without time/circumstance limit irrelevant; wide powers on subjective satisfaction encroach liberty unduly; unlike s.56 which requires witness fear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fails proper balance under Art 19; constitutionally invalid.

holdings.text: Section 57 of Bombay Police Act, 1951 imposes reasonable restrictions under Art 19(5); petition dismissed.
Externment order legal, not based solely on inadmissible material.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld similar provision s.27 City Police Act; reasonableness considers procedure and substance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
State of Madras v. V.G. Row
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasonableness of restrictions; preventive measures precautionary on suspicion.

precedents_cited.case_name: N.B. Khare v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld Act without binding Advisory Board.

Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. State of U.P.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Police Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned for externment; procedure, appeal, judicial review grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Enforcement of fundamental rights; restrictions on freedom.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences for prior conviction triggering s.57.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art 32 challenging s.57 Bombay Police Act and externment order dismissed by majority; section held constitutional as reasonable restriction; dissent by Jagannadhadas J. holding it invalid. No writ or direction issued.

key_quotes.text: "Prevention is better than cure applies not only to individuals but also to the activities of the State in relation to the citizens of the State."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The individuals right to reside in and move freely in any part of the territory of India has to yield to the larger interest of the community."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balances Art 19 rights with public order.

key_quotes.text: "Section 57 of the Act is constitutionally invalid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting holding striking down the section.
